description:
In Guyana, The Ministry of Education wishes to advise that with effect from Monday, March 16, 2020, all schools will be closed for two weeks. This was later extended on March 23rd in another announcement. The extended closure of schools is April 3, which will lead into the Easter Term vacation which runs from April 06, 2020 – April 17, 2020. Schools are set to reopen on April 20.

The University of Guyana (UG) has also extended its closure to March 30th. No updates on opening have been issued for now.
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

description:
In Guyana, the Minister of Public Health has issued emergency measures to contain the spread of the Novel Coronavirus.

It will be in effect from April 3 to May 3, 2020. These measures, among other things, supervised the implementation of a 6 pm to 6 am curfew while only catering for the operations of essential services on a 24-hour basis.

With these emergency measures now published all curfews or measures taken by town councils and village/community leaders and others are revoked except those made by the Ministers responsible for Education, Civil Aviation, Maritime, Immigration and Finance.

In Guyana, the Minister of Public Health has issued emergency measures to contain the spread of the Novel Coronavirus.

UPDATE: Curfew extended to June 3
It will be in effect from April 3 to May 3, 2020. These measures, among other things, supervised the implementation of a 6 pm to 6 am curfew while only catering for the operations of essential services on a 24-hour basis.

With these emergency measures now published all curfews or measures taken by town councils and village/community leaders and others are revoked except those made by the Ministers responsible for Education, Civil Aviation, Maritime, Immigration and Finance. UPDATE: The curfew has been extended for another month. The updated COVID-19 Emergency Measures states that this takes effect from May 4 until June 3, 2020.

In Guyana, the Minister of Public Health has issued emergency measures to contain the spread of the Novel Coronavirus.

It will be in effect from April 3 to May 3, 2020. These measures, among other things, supervised the implementation of a 6 pm to 6 am curfew while only catering for the operations of essential services on a 24-hour basis.

With these emergency measures now published all curfews or measures taken by town councils and village/community leaders and others are revoked except those made by the Ministers responsible for Education, Civil Aviation, Maritime, Immigration and Finance. UPDATE: The COVID-19 Emergency Measures effective until June 3, 2020, has been extended to 17 June 2020, as advised by the National COVID-19 Task Force.
This also means the 6pm-6am curfew will remain in effect until 17 June 2020.

In Guyana, the Minister of Public Health has issued emergency measures to contain the spread of the Novel Coronavirus.

It will be in effect from April 3 to May 3, 2020. These measures, among other things, supervised the implementation of a 6 pm to 6 am curfew while only catering for the operations of essential services on a 24-hour basis.

With these emergency measures now published all curfews or measures taken by town councils and village/community leaders and others are revoked except those made by the Ministers responsible for Education, Civil Aviation, Maritime, Immigration and Finance. UPDATE: The National COVID-19 Task Force has announced that Phase 3 of Guyana’s re-opening process. The national curfew will now be from 8pm (instead of 6pm) to 6am. The curfew shall not apply in Regions 5 and 6 on Mondays to Fridays but shall be in effect on Saturdays and Sundays in these two regions. Outdoor dining at restaurants will be permitted from 6am to 6pm under strict conditions
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
In Guyana, the Minister of Public Health has issued emergency measures to contain the spread of the Novel Coronavirus.

It will be in effect from April 3 to May 3, 2020. These measures, among other things, supervised the implementation of a 6 pm to 6 am curfew while only catering for the operations of essential services on a 24-hour basis.

With these emergency measures now published all curfews or measures taken by town councils and village/community leaders and others are revoked except those made by the Ministers responsible for Education, Civil Aviation, Maritime, Immigration and Finance. UPDATE: National COVID-19 Task Force has announced a six-phase re-opening of Guyana commencing with Phase 1. 
The current curfew of 6pm to 6am will remain in effect for Phase 1 in all administrative regions. The non-curfew measures will be lifted in Regions 5 and 8

In Guyana, the Minister of Public Health has issued emergency measures to contain the spread of the Novel Coronavirus.

It will be in effect from April 3 to May 3, 2020. These measures, among other things, supervised the implementation of a 6 pm to 6 am curfew while only catering for the operations of essential services on a 24-hour basis.

With these emergency measures now published all curfews or measures taken by town councils and village/community leaders and others are revoked except those made by the Ministers responsible for Education, Civil Aviation, Maritime, Immigration and Finance. UPDATE: Phase two of the National COVID-19 Task Force’s six-phase plan to reopen Guyana commences. For Phase 2, all allowances and measures in Phase 1 will be maintained with permission being granted to the manufacturing sector, public sector, construction and medical schools to operate during the non-curfew hours. The 6pm to 6am curfew remains in effect in all administrative regions.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
Guyana to partially close airports amid Coronavirus outbreak. 
Director General of the Guyana Civil Aviation Authority (GCAA) Egbert Fields has announced that airports in the country will be partially shutdown, effective Wednesday, March 18, 2020 – due to the Coronavirus outbreak.

The closure will take effect at midnight and will last for 14 days. The shutdown will mainly apply to incoming international passenger flights at the Cheddi Jagan International Airport (CJIA) and Eugene F Correira International Airport.

The shutdown will not apply to outgoing flights, cargo flights, medevac flights, technical flights, and any other specially authorized flights.
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Guyana’s Cheddi Jagan International Airport (CJIA) and the Eugene Correia International Airport (ECIA) will remain closed to international flights until May 1, 2020. UPDATE: Announced by the Ministry of Public Infrastructure’s social media platforms, Guyana’s Cheddi Jagan International Airport (CJIA) and the Eugene Correia International Airport (ECIA) will remain closed to international flights until May 1, 2020. The closure was previously till April 1st week.

description:
In Guyana, the former Ocean View Hotel located on the Rupert Craig Highway, Liliendaal will be used as a dedicated COVID-19 facility to treat and monitor patients. The facility will house 300 critical patient once it is operational.

Other facilities that are being prepared for COVID -19 treatment are  the former Guyana Broadcasting Corporation building on High Street, the National Gymnasium and the Cliff Anderson Sports Hall. The various COVID-19 facilities will cater for over 1000 patients.

description:
In Guyana, the Ministry of Public Health will soon launch an App that will allow persons to self-test for COVID-19. This is expected to be rolled out on April 5, 2020, on the National Communications Network.

With the app, persons can test themselves for the virus, after which the information will go directly to the surveillance team. After self-testing, persons will be contacted by the surveillance team once they fit any of the following scenarios.

1. If you have traveled and during the 14 days you begin to have a cough, fever or shortness of breath
2. If you have been in contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 and during 14 days since that meeting you begin to have – a cough, fever or shortness of breath.
3. If you visited a facility where COVID-19 positive cases have been identified and during the 14 days after that visit you begin to have a cough, fever or shortness of breath
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
In Guyana, Prime Minister Nagamootoo was appointed to head a National Task Force to coordinate efforts to stop the spread of the virus, which has claimed the life of one imported case from the USA.

The National COVID-19 Task Force headed by the Prime Minister includes the Attorney General and Ministers of Public Health, Public Security, Finance, Foreign Affairs, Education, Communities, Public Infrastructure, Natural Resources, and Citizenship was established on 12th March and completed a national response to the Coronavirus disease.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
In Guyana, President David Granger issued sweeping powers that may include the destruction of personal property, compulsory hospitalization, and the spending of monies from the Consolidated Fund to fight the novel coronavirus (COVID-19). He said his directive remains in force until he withdraws it.

President directed that the virus is an infectious disease that requires the Minister of Public Health to restrain, segregate and isolate persons suffering from the disease or, maybe, likely from exposure to the disease.

The Health Minister has also been authorized to ask the Guyana Police Force for help in enforcing the President’s directives.

The Public Health Minister is also required to take steps to prevent the spread of the disease on the seas, rivers, and waters of Guyana and on the high seas within 12 miles of the baseline as well as on land.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
In light of the increasing number of confirmed cases of the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) in Guyana, and the worrying number of projected cases, the Civil Defence Commission (CDC) has fully activated its National Emergency Operations Centre (NEOC) with effect from March 31, 2020. The activation of the NEOC is aimed at ensuring the highest level of collaboration among all stakeholders is attained to further prevent the spread, enhance preparation and strengthen our local response to the outbreak.

The meeting was conducted utilising a virtual platform and saw representation from the CDC, Ministry of Public Health, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Office of the Prime Minister, United Nations Development Programme, United Nations Children’s Fund, United Nations Population Fund, International Organisation for Migration, Delegation of the European Union in Guyana, National Coordinating Coalition, Food for the Poor, Rotary Guyana and the Caribbean Development Bank.

Based on the meeting’s deliberations, it was agreed that a National Requirements List would be finalised and shared with all partners. The list would continuously be updated to ensure all stakeholders remain apprised of the most urgent needs and work collectively to address these in a timely manner.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: The Government of Guyana is working to ensure that Small businesses benefit from COVID-19 relief grants through the Small Business Bureau.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
In light of the increasing number of confirmed cases of the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) in Guyana, and the worrying number of projected cases, the Civil Defence Commission (CDC) has fully activated its National Emergency Operations Centre (NEOC) with effect from March 31, 2020. The activation of the NEOC is aimed at ensuring the highest level of collaboration among all stakeholders is attained to further prevent the spread, enhance preparation and strengthen our local response to the outbreak.

The meeting was conducted utilising a virtual platform and saw representation from the CDC, Ministry of Public Health, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Office of the Prime Minister, United Nations Development Programme, United Nations Children’s Fund, United Nations Population Fund, International Organisation for Migration, Delegation of the European Union in Guyana, National Coordinating Coalition, Food for the Poor, Rotary Guyana and the Caribbean Development Bank.

Based on the meeting’s deliberations, it was agreed that a National Requirements List would be finalised and shared with all partners. The list would continuously be updated to ensure all stakeholders remain apprised of the most urgent needs and work collectively to address these in a timely manner. UPDATE: The new PPP/C government will be dismantling the politically established National Covid-19 Task Force. A new COVID Response Unit will be established. It will include Government policymakers, represented by the Prime Minister and the Minister of Health, and our regional and international partners such as CARICOM, PAHO, and UNDP.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description:
On April 7, 2020, the Guyana Revenue Authority (GRA) today announced a range of additional tax relief measures that will assist Guyanese as the country grapples with the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic.

The tax relief, the entity stated, will support businesses and individuals who have been socially and economically disadvantaged by the threat of the virus.
type_text: The measures included in this reduction of tax focussed policy are: Removal of VAT on Water and Electricity with effect from April 01, 2020, to June 30, 2020. Removal of VAT on Domestic Air Travel with effect from April 08, 2020, to June 30, 2020. Extension of the April 30 deadline for the filing of tax returns to June 30, 2020. The waiver of VAT and duties on COVID 19 medical supplies and lab testing kits. The granting of tax deductions for all donations made by local businesses to staff and health institutions for the treatment of the virus.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Guyana, the Bartica Town Council is creating a database of persons in the township whose incomes have been affected by the novel coronavirus pandemic.
type_text: The Bartica Town Council is creating a database of persons in the township whose incomes have been affected by the novel coronavirus pandemic. This way when the municipality receives resources, they will know to whom to direct these resources
target_geog_level: One or more cities within a country
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The government will turn its attention to stimulus packages for vulnerable Guyanese who have been most affected by the novel coronavirus (COVID-19), as soon as the country moves past its current hurdle.
type_text: The government will turn its attention to stimulus packages for vulnerable Guyanese who have been most affected by the novel coronavirus (COVID-19), as soon as the country moves past its current hurdle. In the meantime, the government is seeking to establish a database of all persons whose lives have been severely affected by the still growing pandemic.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Early Pension Payment to commence April 29 in Guyana. GPOC said the new measure effectively safeguards and ensures elderly persons can collect their pensions payments during COVID-19 pandemic.
type_text: The Guyana Post Office Corporation (GPOC) has announced that the payment of Old Age Pensions will commence on April 29, 2020, at 07:00 hours at all post offices countrywide. GPOC said the new measure effectively safeguards and ensures elderly persons can collect their pensions payments during COVID-19 pandemic.

description: A partnership between the Civil Defence Commission and the Guyana Council of Organisations for Persons with Disabilities will see over 700 persons benefiting from relief hampers during the current COVID-19 epidemic.
type_text: Distribution exercise of relief hampers to persons living with disabilities in Region Five, Six and Ten. The initiative is to assist the most vulnerable groups and will provide members with much-needed supplies.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: Guyanese medical students studying in Cuba are set to receive care packages from the Department of Public Service
type_text: Guyana sent parcels containing food supplies and sanitary items on Thursday to Guyanese medical students studying in Cuba
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The National COVID-19 Task Force in Guyana reviewed the emergency measures, post-June 3, in relation to the possible phased re-opening of the economy and airspace
type_text: The meeting considered the applications of various groups of Guyanese overseas who want to return home. In this regard some of these requests were approved as part of controlled re-entry measures.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Municipal Government,Police

description: Within the coming days, 103 Guyanese abroad will return to these nation’s shores after permission was granted by the National COVID-19 Task Force
type_text: Under the controlled re-entry measures, 19 law students in Trinidad, 70 Royal Caribbean cruise ship employees, 4 citizens in St. Vincent and 10 in Sint Marteen have all had their requests to return to Guyana approved.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Police

description: The Ministry of Social Protection, Guyana has accelerated its services and will be providing support to eligible citizens.
type_text: provision of much needed tangible support for vulnerable households affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Civil Defense Commission of Guyana has rolled out a COVID-19 Pandemic Assistance Voucher Programme.
type_text: The objective of the programme is to provide relief to vulnerable citizens during the COVID-19 pandemic through the supply of hampers and care items.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Justice,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: UNICEF together with its partners, the Childcare and Protection Agency (CPA), Blossom Inc. and the Regional Democratic Council (RDC)-Region 10, on Wednesday, July 8, 2020, opened a one-stop “Child Advocacy Centre” (CAC) in Kwakwani, for the reporting and treatment of child sexual abuse.
type_text: As of June 2020, the number of reports of child sexual abuse in Guyana exceeded 200 and access to services are critical, given the possible increased rates of violence due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
target_geog_level: One or more cities within a country
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Inmates in Guyana have begun to be released to address overcrowding in the prisons in light of the COVID-19 pandemic.
type_text: As it relates to persons who were granted release specifically in light of COVID, those are persons who have been granted remission. All persons who are admitted to the prison are subjected to 14 days quarantine.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Justice,Police

description: In Guyana, the People’s Progressive Party’s has initiated a ‘Mask Up’ campaign and is set to distribute 10,000 masks across Guyana starting 9th April in Region 4.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Partnering with the Ministry of Public Health, UNICEF launched a digital platform to facilitate community engagement, to improve efforts to address the COVID-19 pandemic and to protect children from its direct and knock-on consequences.
type_sub_cat: Gathering information related to COVID-19 from the public

description: The Government of Guyana, today, launched a data collection mechanism, which is aimed at identifying and providing tangible support for vulnerable households affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and its emergency measures.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
In keeping with safeguards to prevent an outbreak, more than a dozen family members of Guyana’s first novel coronavirus [COVID-19] victim (confirmed on March 11, 2020) are quarantined. This was confirmed by 
the Public Relations and Health Promotion Officer within the Ministry of Public Health, Mr. Terrence Esseboom on March 12.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: The Georgetown Public Hospital Corporation has established a COVID-19 Maternity Unit. This is a specified quarantine/isolation unit within the department to house pregnant women who are suspected to have COVID-19.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within a country

description: In Guyana, as the first wave of stranded Guyanese makes their way home during the second week of June, all will be subjected to a mandatory seven-day quarantine at their homes.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
In keeping with safeguards to prevent an outbreak, more than a dozen family members of Guyana’s first novel coronavirus [COVID-19] victim (confirmed on March 11, 2020) are quarantined. This was confirmed by 
the Public Relations and Health Promotion Officer within the Ministry of Public Health, Mr. Terrence Esseboom on March 12. UPDATE: Arriving passengers will be expected to wear their facial masks at all times. Travelers with negative PCR test results will undergo a 7-day quarantine period. Other travellers who had the PCR test done on the day of flight and the results are not available will be subject to 14 days quarantine
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
In Guyana, the Bartica Town Council has put into effect a “Stay Home” advisory as of 18:00hrs (6 pm) on March 28, 2020.

“It is not a curfew; it is not a lockdown…. But we are calling on all Barticians and by extension the residents of Region Seven to do two things; be on the road for work purposes only and two only be on the road to access essential services,” Mayor Marshall said.

The advisory will be in effect for two weeks from March 28 to April 10, 2020. The orders which take effect from 6pm March 28 are as follows:

-The immediate closure of all public sporting venues utilized for sports and recreation namely the Bartica Sports Complex, Mongrippa playfield, other recreational parks.
- Closure of taxi parks, bus parks, and taxi catchment points.
- To ensure social distancing is being implemented  the advisory also recommends that there is no gathering at bars, restaurants and barbershops or salons; proprietors must engage customers through minimal contact options.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down

description:
In Guyana, the Georgetown Mayor and City Council will be closing all municipal markets effective from Saturday, April 4, 2020, as it continues to implement temporary measures to put an end the spread of the novel coronavirus.

A public notice issued by the Municipality’s Markets Department on Thursday stated that all markets and street vending operations must cease from Friday, April 3, 2020, at 7pm.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down

description: In Guyana, National COVID-19 Task Force held an emergency multi-stakeholder meeting on the alarming increase in confirmed COVID-19 cases in parts of regions 1 and 7. Decisions were taken to implement enhanced containment measures within the affected areas. These include ceasing work orders for specific areas in the mining sector, screening, wider testing, checkpoints, and other measures in several locations within regions 1 and 7.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Mining and quarrying") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
In Guyana, all ‘in person’ hearings have been suspended until further notice.
“These updated directions in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic are in addition to the Supreme Court of Judicature Practice Directions COVID-19 Emergency Directions, Gazetted on 23rd March, 2020.” The Supreme Court stated in a media release.
With immediate effect, the court said these measures will be in place lasting until April 24, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
In Guyana, The Protected Areas Commission (PAC) and the National Parks Commission (NPC) at this time would like to advise the general public that the Georgetown Zoo will be closed beginning Tuesday 17th March 2020 until further notice.

Please be advised also that the Botanical Gardens and the National Park will remain open as we take extra precautionary measures to ensure that all of our public facilities are fully sanitized.

In Guyana, President David Granger, on Thursday (2nd April), announced that in order to strengthen containment measures against COVID-19, with effect from midnight (23:59 hours) on Friday 3rd April 2020, the government will close public gathering at places of entertainment, including bars, clubs, gymnasiums, night clubs, restaurants, and swimming pools, between the hours of 18:00 hours and 06:00 hours (6:00 pm and 6 am).
The second Guyana Trade and Investment Exhibition (GuyTIE) scheduled for May, 2020 has been postponed until further notice.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
In Guyana, The Protected Areas Commission (PAC) and the National Parks Commission (NPC) at this time would like to advise the general public that the Georgetown Zoo will be closed beginning Tuesday 17th March 2020 until further notice.

Please be advised also that the Botanical Gardens and the National Park will remain open as we take extra precautionary measures to ensure that all of our public facilities are fully sanitized. UPDATE: Guyana's Protected Areas Commission said that the national park will open from 6:30 am to 5 pm Monday to Friday but will remain closed on weekends.

In Guyana, to protect our senior citizens during this period when they are the most vulnerable to the Coronavirus (COVID-19), we are working to implement standardized measures across the Post Offices in every region to treat with the potential threat of the virus effectively.

Of grave concern to the management of the Guyana Post Office Corporation (GPOC), is the trend of thousands of senior citizens accessing pension payments during the first and second day of the new month. 

We are therefore vehemently encouraging senior citizens to refrain from visiting the Post Offices during the first two days of the month unless it is absolutely necessary. Senior citizens can also authorize their family members to uplift their pension payments.
Visits to Guyana’s prisons have been replaced with video calls amid the coronavirus pandemic.
